repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Improving service delivery and
            accountability through information technology and capacity development

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            strengthening the public financial management in Malawi.
            Malawi, like many countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, made only
            modest progress in achieving fiscal discipline and
            operational efficiency in the public service. Lack of
            effective financial management, audit and procurement
            functions in the public sector continued to hamper the
            government's ability to function effectively. The
            Financial Management Transparency and Accountability Project
            (FIMTAP) was designed to provide a toolkit of solutions to
            poor fiscal discipline, transparency, accountability and
            operational inefficiency in the public service. The project
            introduced new payroll and human resource management and
            debt management systems. An effective Integrated Financial
            Management Information System was linked to the budget
            development system, to streamline budget and cost estimates.
            All government bank accounts was consolidated into a
            Treasury Single Account, to better control public debt
            management, and provide control over the public wage bill.

12642004.trustfund:
TF090947-MALAWI PUBLIC FINANCIAL
            MANAGEMENT CHILD TRUST FUND

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Financial Management,
            Transparency, and Accountability Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Management,
            Transparency, and Accountability Project for Malawi were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the project design should be simple and designed
            for easy implementation and should take into account the
            absorptive capacity of the country and the prevailing
            political context. For efficient use of available resources
            in a country, project design should take account of grant
            financing from donors, which however, requires more flexible
            design of capacity building activities. This will minimize
            duplication of efforts, and encourage cost effectiveness.
            Changes in political economy are not predictable, but could
            be better adapted to if project design allowed greater
            flexibility in implementation. It is pertinent therefore, to
            constantly evaluate and adapt to change in circumstances to
            better maneuver public management reform programs.
            Candidness in project supervision reporting is essential, as
            is early management attention to emerging problems. A
            project should not proceed with Board presentation unless a
            full technical appraisal and feasibility study of its
            components have been conducted. Inter-ministerial and donor
            coordination is crucial to the success of project implementation.

7005755.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Financial Management,
            Transparency, and Accountability Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Management, Transparency,
            and Accountability Project (FIMTAP) for Malawi aims to
            improve an effective and accountable use of public
            expenditures through capacity building and institutional
            strengthening for budget implementation and oversight, and
            increase transparency of government institutions, as well as
            to improve human and institutional capacity for expenditure
            accountability. The project seeks to strengthen expenditure,
            improve financial management systems, and enhance human
            capital development. There are four components to the
            project: strengthening accountability institutions to reduce
            corruption, and improve allocation and utilization of
            resources; improve financial management that will
            electronically link Government with an integrated financial
            management system to provide data; and human development to
            support the creation of critical skills needed in areas of
            financial management, auditing, accounting, management, and
            information technology; and FIMTAP Secretariat - the project
            will be managed by the FIMTAP Secretariat.
